Great follow-up—here’s what a strong plan and success definition typically look like on our team.

(1) Strong first 60–90 day plan
• Days 0–30 (Ramp + align): onboard to our product/workflow, meet key partners, review current roadmap/tech/process, and co-author a short “problem brief” for your first project (goal, non-goals, constraints, success metrics, risks). You’d also start contributing small PRs/changes to learn the codebase and release process.
• Days 31–60 (Own a scoped project end-to-end): take ownership of a well-defined deliverable—drive requirements clarification, propose approach/tradeoffs, execute, and ship behind a feature flag if needed. Establish a weekly update cadence with stakeholders.
• Days 61–90 (Deliver impact + set next bets): iterate based on feedback/metrics, harden reliability/edge cases, document what you built, and propose the next 1–2 improvements or follow-on projects with a clear ROI.

(2) How we measure success in first 3–6 months
We look for a mix of delivery, quality, and operating maturity:
• Delivery: shipped 1 meaningful project (or a sequence of smaller releases) that stakeholders can point to.
• Outcomes/metrics: agreed-upon KPI movement where applicable (e.g., cycle time reduction, adoption/usage, error rate reduction, performance, or cost). For some projects, the “metric” is a capability delivered on time with clear acceptance criteria.
• Execution quality: predictable progress, good written updates/docs, thoughtful tradeoffs, and low rework.
• Collaboration: strong partner feedback—PM/design/eng peers feel informed and unblocked.

Hiring timeline
We’re actively interviewing now. If there’s mutual interest, we aim to complete interviews and make a decision within ~2–3 weeks (sometimes faster depending on scheduling).

To make this concrete: what kind of work are you most excited to own next (0→1 vs. optimization/scale), and what’s your ideal decision timeline? If Company_D is in your top set, we can align quickly on next steps.
